The builders of the Empire State Building faced numerous obstacles in attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there. A mooring mast, intended for docking dirigibles, would add significant stress to the building's frame and "could not simply be dropped atop the Empire State Building." The building needed to be extensively "modified and strengthened" to accommodate this situation, requiring substantial engineering changes. Most dirigibles from outside of the United States used hydrogen, which is extremely flammable. Owners of the building realized if an accident like the Hindenburg disaster were to take place above a densely populated city or area such as downtown New York, the results would have been far worse, causing catastrophic loss of life. The builders' greatest obstacle would be nature itself. Winds atop the building were constantly shifting due to violent air currents, making stable docking nearly impossible. Even if the airship could tether to the mast, the back of the ship would swivel dangerously around the mooring mast. In addition, due to an existing law against airships flying too low over urban areas, dirigibles could not legally moor at the Empire State Building. For these combined reasons, "The mooring mast of the Empire State Building was destined to never fulfill its purpose," remaining an ambitious but impractical feature.
